item.title: Business Telephone Systems Hosted VoIP Advantages
item.description: Businesses of all sizes have various choices for their telephone systems. Small businesses can buy systems from local stores, while medium-sized businesses often work with contractors for key telephone systems or small PBXs. Larger companies may have internal teams that handle complex telephone systems. Nowadays, hosted VoIP is a cost-effective option for companies of all sizes. How can one solution meet the needs of different-sized businesses affordably? It’s not a one-size-fits-all solution but a scalable technology adaptable to different demandsâ€”hosted VoIP, also known as hosted PBX or cloud telephone systems.

item.title: Ethernet Over Fiber Needed By Business
item.description: While many believe fiber optic bandwidth is the way of the future, it’s already a smart choice for businesses today. Traditionally, businesses have depended on copper-based telecom services. The copper wiring integrated during a building’s construction becomes the backbone for multi-line phone systems, ISDN digital trunking for PBX systems, and T1 lines connecting offices and providing broadband internet. This infrastructure has been the standard for many small and medium-sized businesses for decades.

item.title: Your Chance to Invent Payphone 2.0
item.description: Remember payphones? Before cellphones, they were everywhere, especially in busy areas. Now that everyone has a cellphone, you might think payphones are gone, like horses and buggies. Not quite. Public payphones are still important for communication. Think about Hurricane Sandy: cell towers failed, and people desperately needed to communicate. VoIP and broadband were also down. Surprisingly, old payphones still worked. You could just insert coins and make a call. Why did old technology work when modern technology failed?

item.title: Fiber Lit Towers Improving Rural Broadband
item.description: Living outside the city limits often means limited internet options. While options like 3G and satellite exist, they come with slow speeds and download caps. Businesses might have access to slightly better choices like T1 lines, but high-speed options are generally nonexistent. Rural areas face a digital disadvantage compared to cities where gigabit and even 10 gigabit ethernet connections are readily available. Fixed wireless and cable options also offer much faster speeds in these areas.
